This might however quickly progress to using bitcoin or ethereum in the later stages where even a card wouldn’t be necessary. We are constantly working to make the shift from fiat currencies to digital currencies for greater economic values are sustained and generated.I do not recall of a single instance in the past two months where I physically handled cash. I use android Pay for buying groceries, and Bank of America ATMs at San Francisco Caltrain Station and at Boston JFK&UMASS station come well equipped with contactless sensors where I’m not required to whip out my wallet for debit cards at all, that being said none of my wallets have ever held cash in them since 11th grade,easily 3+ years ago.Bio Sensors are quite prevalent in phones nowadays and I wouldn’t be surprised if they found their way to making transactions on a regular basis.I strongly believe that Bio Sensors shall be used later down in the future as means of convenient and secure payment systems integrated with the blockchain.In fact, I do recall documenting a similar thought as such for a patent application. I’d be more than willing to discuss it if anybody is interested.Paper bills are highly outdated, but given that not everyone shall be able to switch immediately, it shall certainly be a gradual change,but it shall happen nevertheless.Reference:7 Surprising Biometric Identification MethodsWhat will be the impact of demonetization in India and how could it have been minimized?

Answer: Answering: What kind of advanced technologies would replace paper bills (banknotes)?Today (late 2016) in the United State, only maybe 10 percent of the money supply is is the from of currency (paper bills and coin); the rest of the money supply consists of entries in electronic databases. Many people just use currency for convenience purchases, but make the bulk of their purchases using credit cards, debit cards, Apple pay, and other forms of electronic payment. So existing technology has already began to replace currency, and the portion of the US money supply kept as currency has been declinAnswering: What kind of advanced technologies would replace paper bills (banknotes)?Today (late 2016) in the United State, only maybe 10 percent of the money supply is is the from of currency (paper bills and coin); the rest of the money supply consists of entries in electronic databases. Many people just use currency for convenience purchases, but make the bulk of their purchases using credit cards, debit cards, Apple pay, and other forms of electronic payment. So existing technology has already began to replace currency, and the portion of the US money supply kept as currency has been declining for a good 20 years owing to advancing technology. So especially in a city like New York, San Francisco, or Boston, an average person could probably go through the week without using currency at all. (Which would be an interesting experiment, by the way.)

Answer: I grew up in a very small town. In the winter, the Fire Department would creat an ice skating rink in the town square and when school wasn’t in session, there would be a lot of kids, between 4 years old and 16 years old, all sharing the ice.Hockey games would break out. We’d play whiplash. Everyone had fun. Everyone got a lot of exercise. There were very few overweight kids.Television became prevalent and the ice rink faded away due to fewer and fewer using it.There were weight issues popping up in school.Kids quit interacting with each other as much.Today, the ice would be empty.Summertime waI grew up in a very small town. In the winter, the Fire Department would creat an ice skating rink in the town square and when school wasn’t in session, there would be a lot of kids, between 4 years old and 16 years old, all sharing the ice.Hockey games would break out. We’d play whiplash. Everyone had fun. Everyone got a lot of exercise. There were very few overweight kids.Television became prevalent and the ice rink faded away due to fewer and fewer using it.There were weight issues popping up in school.Kids quit interacting with each other as much.Today, the ice would be empty.Summertime was a different issue. It was cooler outside at 90 degrees than it was inside. No Air Conditioning.At 8 AM we’d all be outside playing baseball or catch or fishing or . . .We might come in to eat lunch.After dinner about 6 PM we’d play hide and seek.No overweight kids.Technology, in the form of TV and Air Conditioning, changed that.Just like the ice rink.Social Media has been the silver bullet in the heart.

Answer: “Hello, I am struggling to find a job for the summer. Can you help me?”I receive several of these requests every month, on Quora or LinkedIn. I try to be a nice guy and help when I can but a request like that tells me why you are struggling to find a job.“Hello, I am struggling to find a job for the summer. Can you help me?”I receive several of these requests every month, on Quora or LinkedIn. I try to be a nice guy and help when I can but a request like that tells me why you are struggling to find a job.The Importance Of SpecificityRichard Nesbitt and Lee Ross conducted an experiment with Stanford students, who were asked to list the most generous students they knew as well as the most selfish.Lists were created and the researchers contacted these groups, asking them to contribute to a food drive. They split them into two groups, with the difference being instructions given.The first group was given a vague “Dear Student” request asking them to donate food and telling them where they could drop it off and when.The second group was given much more specific direction. They were addressed by name in the letter, given direction on specific foods to bring (i.e. Creamed Corn), a map directing them to the drop box, a specific time to visit and then a follow-up call reminding them of what they learned in the letter.Even one in four jerks showed up with some creamed cornMake It Easy To Help YouWhen I suggest to a job seeker that they need to approach as many decision makers as possible, I often hear “I’ve tried that, it doesn’t work.”Perhaps, you have tried. How many did you reach out to? Five? Ten? How about 500? How bad to do you want a better job?Your alternative is starting your own business and I assure you that you will reach out to far more strangers than 500 to accomplish that.How easy are you making it on those you reach out to? Are you leaving them with open-ended requests to help you?How many decisions do they have to make when they open your email?They now have one decision to make. They can forward the email to someone in their network, who is most likely junior to their position if you did the homework. Or, they can delete your email.It is still likely they will not help you, just like 75% of the jerks in the study still didn’t donate to the food drive. That said, you give yourself a much better chance of sparking an action on your behalf if you are clear, direct and ask for something that requires a quick decision or action.Do the work for the person you need help from. Make it easy to help you.

Answer: I am not a tech expert, merely an end-user speaking only to our daily use of digital devices for communication and information. Though I am competent on several of these and adopt learning curves as needed, I often grow annoyed at the greedily rabid speed of development/upgrading on my devices. Besides creating and feeding the artificially addictive need to possess the ‘latest and greatest’ issue, the cost of upgrades has gone through the roof for most people and contributed significantly to the world’s trash piles. If development stopped now on these things, I would only have one request: thaI am not a tech expert, merely an end-user speaking only to our daily use of digital devices for communication and information. Though I am competent on several of these and adopt learning curves as needed, I often grow annoyed at the greedily rabid speed of development/upgrading on my devices. Besides creating and feeding the artificially addictive need to possess the ‘latest and greatest’ issue, the cost of upgrades has gone through the roof for most people and contributed significantly to the world’s trash piles. If development stopped now on these things, I would only have one request: that companies put their development budgets towards perpetual support for current devices. To answer your question more specifically, I’d have to say that any technology, particularly medical, that is dedicated to keeping us safe and healthy should not be stopped.

A suit that allows you to breathe? Sure, with GIANT tanks attached to it, for a couple hours.Let’s break down what the suit is and why we can’t have nice things… yet. (and I’m not even going to use the new nano particle suit, just the one from Iron Man I - the very first movie, the basic suit).Fully enclosed suit:We are nowhere near it.Nowhere. Not even slightly.An exoskeleton that allows the user to have greater strength for lifting in specific circumstances? Yes. But not a suit. A suit that allows you to breathe? Sure, with GIANT tanks attached to it, for a couple hours.Let’s break down what the suit is and why we can’t have nice things… yet. (and I’m not even going to use the new nano particle suit, just the one from Iron Man I - the very first movie, the basic suit).Fully enclosed suit:Self contained:Tiny Power Source:Inertia Dampening:Recycling:Strength actuators:Mind Interface:The suit is slow, and easily overcome by attackers if you manipulate it any other way thanRepulsorsAIExotic materials:Actual Holographic displays:As you see any ONE of these inventions would revolutionize its industry and change our lives for the better, but you need ALL of them to replicate his suit. You need the actuators to give it the stretch but the suit would fall apart from stress so you need the exotic materials but then you need to power it so you need a power source that generates enough power in a tiny space that doesn’t kill the wearer with radiation and heat, but you can’t fly unless you have repulsors and then you can’t control it because you don’t have the mind interface, but then you are limited in what you can do unless you have the most advanced and complete and benign AI installed but you can’t do that unless you have the computing power that is insanely powerful in a tiny space and none of that matters because a couple hits from physical attacks would turn your body and brain to jelly from the outside shocks so you need electronic inertial dampeners that would put the Enterprise to shame.And that’s why we can’t have nice things.PS - I’m sure I missed something. :)

Answer: All species have a range and when that range is filled, those who live there must compete with one another over limited resources.Humans evolved from lowland apes in Africa. When we filled that range some humans created new technologies of clothing, fire and shelter to extend their range. This expanded range is called the frontier. New resources are found in the frontier enriching all. In this environment cooperation is favoured over competition, since cooperation brings more resources from the frontier into the center enriching us all.In the present age our frontier is interplanetary space, aAll species have a range and when that range is filled, those who live there must compete with one another over limited resources.Humans evolved from lowland apes in Africa. When we filled that range some humans created new technologies of clothing, fire and shelter to extend their range. This expanded range is called the frontier. New resources are found in the frontier enriching all. In this environment cooperation is favoured over competition, since cooperation brings more resources from the frontier into the center enriching us all.In the present age our frontier is interplanetary space, and beyond that, interstellar space. Interplanetary space is traverse by chemical rockets. The first large chemical rockets were developed in the 1940s and advanced continuously since. Investment in rocket technology reduces the cost of momentum delivered by rockets. This increases the mass flow per dollar between points where the change in speed is fixed to connect the two places. Thus development follows a well defined arc;At this point serious investment in lowering the cost of momentum delivered by rockets was abandoned. Project funding for atomic rockets was ended, and previously declassified materials were reclassified. Had funding and focus continued apace we would have hadThe founding of Space in 2002 resulted in a rocket with a reusable first stage. This dramatically cut the cost of space launch and allowed SpaceX to come to dominate space launch and earn significant profits doing so.It takes 52 days 16 hours to fly to Pluto at 1/10th gee using photonic thrusters.To perform interstellar trips requires vastly more energy. Yet, that energy is available from the Sun. The way we tap the sun’s energy at the scale needed is by creating an optical machine made of plasma. You see, the refractive index of hot plasmas changes with temperature. So, by projecting a pattern of laser light into the chromosphere to create an optical element that is capable of communicating, computing, generating controlled laser beams, and making copies of itself. So, taking an hour to replicate, projecting a single square meter of plasmonic structure into the sun it takes only 62.4 hours to cover the entire sun with an array of such machines, and capture 18% of the sun’s luminosity for human use. The entire sun may be considered a single optical element and thus can project similar patterns to nearby stars. Those stars signal back their status, and repeat the process, expanding outward. In this ways the interplanetary cyclers are upgraded to interstellar cycler operating at 1 gee. The sun boosts the photonic thruster at 1 gee to the half way point and light originating from the destination star slows the ship’s speed beyond that point. In this way humanity will be able to travel freely across the galaxy.All products and services diffuse into use in a well defined way.It is no different for interplanetary settlement or interstellar settlement. The interesting aspect it that population grows at 1.06% and even with unlimited life span, population wil grow at less than 2%. Innovators constitute 2.5% of the population, whilst Early adopters constitute 13.5%. So as soon as cost effective interplanetary travel and interstellar travel is available everyone will make use of it within 20 to 40 years, and the Earth will be depopulated, and later, the Solar System will be depopulated.Time Dilation and the Ultimate FrontierNow, after travelling 2.15 light years at 1 gee acceleration — half way to the nearest star — a ship attains 95.15% light speed slowing time aboard ship (and reproductive rate) by 3.25x. This distance is half way to the nearest star. Longer distances produce even higher speeds and higher dilations. Creating extreme dilations in time. This means that populations that are moving across the galaxy do not reproduce until they get to where they are going. Yet, the loss rate of ships scales with distance. At some point the loss at a given range equals the total births within the volume of the sphere with that range. Beyond that range, the number of humans fall off. Humans becoming increasingly rare beyond this range. Even if starships are safer than sitting in your living room, this will occur because of time dilation.This is the final condition of a technical species. Occupying a sphere of over a billion stars that is 10,000 light years across, commanding vast material and energy resources, living a cooperative life style in a post scarcity civilisation.

Answer: Humans are very likely evolving faster today than at almost any time in the past. Sounds crazy, right? How could this be? Let me explain.Most people think of evolution as operating on members of a species with “inferior” traits, thereby reducing their survivability and ultimate contribution to the gene pool. With this understanding, you’d then point to our modern longevity and note that “humans have largely solved the problem of survivability” — which we have. We can remedy poor eyesight, compensate for chronic diseases, vaccinate against plagues, work around infertility, etc. But this understHumans are very likely evolving faster today than at almost any time in the past. Sounds crazy, right? How could this be? Let me explain.Most people think of evolution as operating on members of a species with “inferior” traits, thereby reducing their survivability and ultimate contribution to the gene pool. With this understanding, you’d then point to our modern longevity and note that “humans have largely solved the problem of survivability” — which we have. We can remedy poor eyesight, compensate for chronic diseases, vaccinate against plagues, work around infertility, etc. But this understanding is based on a narrow view of evolution.Evolution operates at a species wide level across vast periods of time. And what is it looking for? You might say, “survival of the fittest” or “natural selection”. And that’s where a lot of the confusion comes from. With ever longer lifespans and no natural predators, evolution seems to be way back in the rear view mirror for Homo sapiens. But what evolution really cares about isSo if we want to see if humans are evolving, we need to look for any signs ofSource:A Tale of Two Fertilities - Africa and Everywhere Else. Source:BOTTOM LINE: As a direct consequence of the pressures ofUs Today:Us in 2200:Sources:Disclaimers and Other Cool StuffEDIT - 11/15/2018: Answer heavily edited based on feedback from fellow Quorans. You people are smart and make things better.

Answer: Too many of us would be dead, due to loss of vaccination and modern medicine, along with loss of agriculture (it requires tools and lots of work), reliable water (no dams, wells, reservoirs, etc.), shelter (no housing), and much more. Near-sighted folks like me would be helpless without glasses. No books, so the greatest ability to store and retrieve information is gone.Any successful survivors would be frantically recreating whatever technology they could, and the best results would go to those who could best organize themselves for cooperative effort.

Answer: In real life, lots of things were “invented” long before they could be practically built. The long evolution of firearms is the perfect example. People could imagine better guns, but they couldn’t actually build them, because the metallurgy and materials science and manufacturing science wasn’t advanced enough. So everyone could see the advantages of breechloading rifles over muzzleloading muskets. But building one that wouldn’t explode in your hands was another matter entirely. Making effective breechloaders didn’t require someone to have a flash of insight, it required lots of plain ploddingIn real life, lots of things were “invented” long before they could be practically built. The long evolution of firearms is the perfect example. People could imagine better guns, but they couldn’t actually build them, because the metallurgy and materials science and manufacturing science wasn’t advanced enough. So everyone could see the advantages of breechloading rifles over muzzleloading muskets. But building one that wouldn’t explode in your hands was another matter entirely. Making effective breechloaders didn’t require someone to have a flash of insight, it required lots of plain plodding evolutionary steps in manufacturing high strength metal parts to extremely fine tolerances.In real life the idea for an invention is the easy part. Making a prototype that actually kind-of, sort-of works is another. Making something that will work reliably is another. Making something that can be mass produced is another. Making something that can be mass produced and sold at a profit is another. Making mass producing and selling your product into a profitable business is yet another.So the idea of “take some dragonpowder, stuff it into a tube with a handle, stuff a lump of plumbum in, and set off the dragonpowder with a length of burning rope” is all well and good. Getting a weapon that will hit the broad side of a barn, with enough force to at least dent the boards, without explodinating in your face, is quite another. And in real life it took hundreds of years of design improvements and battlefield testing before gunpowder weapons changed from a curiosity to proven war-winning technology.In any case, early gunpowder weapons aren’t, in my opinion, a game-breaking technology, since in reality they were present in the late medieval battlefield, but weren’t all that useful. Longbowmen and crossbowmen were still much better than arquebusiers.Early gunpowder weapons would mix in just fine with knights in shining armor and wood elf bowmen and magic missile slinging wizards. So if you’ve got a dwarf who wants a hand cannon, then feel free to let him have one. The only problem is if you make those early gunpowder weapons work as effectively as modern firearms. They were heavy, loud, had one shot, took a very long time to reload, and were inaccurate as hell.
name: David Bushey
question: https://www.quora.com/What-kind-of-advanced-technologies-would-replace-paper-bills-banknotes

Answer: Budget for one. Inventing stuff is expensive, even more expensive than you may think and even without prooftesting and optimisation. If someone makes something in their garage it’s an already invented thing for which they can get the parts that they need to combine into one, because you’re not inventing something completely new like a time machine with anything short of university-level funding and time.Difficulty. Do not underestimate how difficult it is to go from scrap to something. For the consumer it may sound easy because factories are using machines and kids to make phones, but the inveBudget for one. Inventing stuff is expensive, even more expensive than you may think and even without prooftesting and optimisation. If someone makes something in their garage it’s an already invented thing for which they can get the parts that they need to combine into one, because you’re not inventing something completely new like a time machine with anything short of university-level funding and time.Difficulty. Do not underestimate how difficult it is to go from scrap to something. For the consumer it may sound easy because factories are using machines and kids to make phones, but the invention process is no laughing matter or just ‘I want more, so I added more’. I myself just finished a 7.5 month internship trying to improve the sound volume of screenprinted piezoelectric loudspeakers, and even with full 40h/week work hours and most equipment readily available you’d be surprised how little you fit in those 7.5 months because everything takes longer than you’d expect. Also, how much extra time you lose on documentation, calculations and showing your progress to people and in reports. I’d once heard from someone in the Hollywood CGI business that professionals make an estimate of how long they need to animate some scene, and that the producers then double or tripple that time as the soft deadline of when to expect it.Availability. What you want to do, has to be available. You never quite find the right materials or properties that you need during initial production. You’d think that getting polyethylene glycol substrates that are a bit thinner than what I had would be easy, but no. Not to mention finding chemicals with the right properties that don’t also come with several production or side-effect problems. During inventing you don’t have the perfectly-fitting-together and optimal size and properties stuff that the factories use, you have to use materials that you wouldn’t use for the final product just to get things optimal enough for them to work at all (like using platina electrodes instead of the lesser electrodes you’d use later, which are too expensive for the final product).Getting the idea at all. A lot of inventions seem obvious or simple now that we have them, doesn’t mean that they were that obvious and easy when they didn’t exist yet.

Answer: Succinctly? The DM’s right (and in many cases responsibility) to preserve his or her campaign as conceptualized and envisioned.In more detail? Frankly, whether ambitious and willful players like it or not, a DM has more than sufficient justification to say,Succinctly? The DM’s right (and in many cases responsibility) to preserve his or her campaign as conceptualized and envisioned.In more detail? Frankly, whether ambitious and willful players like it or not, a DM has more than sufficient justification to say,Now, sometimes, this is just inflexibility on the part of a DM. If that’s the case, and the participants can’t talk it out, one has to consider finding another game. I mean, if the character is conducting research in a campaign that seems toBut if the DM is running a historical fantasy campaign set in, say, Israel in the time of Saul, David and Solomon, and the player is bound and determined to invent and mass distribute gunpowder or its magical equivalent (jeweler’s rouge, anyone?), said player, in quite childish fashion, is directly defying the tone and tenor of the campaign.Talk to the player and explain how this line of research is doomed to failure for both in- and meta-game reasons. If the player accepts that, work with him or her on options that will satisfy but not disrupt. (Put him or her on the cutting edge of the invention and distribution of iron weapons, for example.) Problem solved.If instead, he or she cops a serious ’tude, and starts going on with “that’s not fair” or (God help you) uses the phrase, “player agency,” well …… then, the DM must act: Lay down the law, gently but firmly, and let it be known that the discussion is over. If the player sullenly, stubbornly persists,Hopefully it never comes to that … but, whether you’re Matt Mercer or the Mad Hatter, some people will just never be happy in your campaigns.
